reviewText:
Its not a bad game but it has problems:

Its too difficult for casual play - cars speed away from you even on very easy setting. And this is ona  straight so its no reflection of the quality of the driving. There no way they should do that on an easy setting.

Controller setting are minimal. Its ok if you have an 'advanced wheel' (whatever one of those is) but I have a joystick and you cant config it at all. No sensitivity settings for travelling at speed so you waver all over the track. Plus the game when I played it kept losing my controller settings every time I restarted. Also when I set the controller to joystick I couldnt use Esc to exit a session the only way to get out of a session was to stop on a racetrack and get black listed! You cant even exit from the pits. Terrible settings, terrible configuration.

The car AI is abysmal. They dont go around you they barge you off the track every time.

Otherwise its not a bad game, graphics are good, I had no crashes in the short time I was trying the game, pits looked good, communications with the team were really good. And of course this is probably the only game where you can play the current season without mods.

In the end I used Steam refund policy to try the game and ended up getting a refund and bought Project Cars which is a far far far better game all around. But even rFactor2 is better than this game in terms of options, immersion, AI and driving experience.

reviewText:
I feel the game is now at a point where it is actually worth looking at. The launch was terrible and I am glad the reviews were bad and Codemasters lost money. There is no excuse for that garbage they put out earlier this year. But after ~10 patches the game is finally good.

The good:- Graphics are beautiful and performance is fine
- The AI is fantastic
- The handling is better and doesn't feel like you are driving on rails
- Actual performance differences between the cars - you won't be able to win with a Honda
- More management from the driver is needed during the race (tyres, fuel, engine, brakes,...)
- Dynamic weather
- Great presentation and feel
- Includes 2014 and 2015 season (which means we get Hockenheim)
- FOV settings

The bad:- Multiplayer is a cluster♥♥♥♥ and not enjoyable
- Some things feel scripted and not simulated

Verdict:It is in my opinion the best F1 game we've had in years. It took a while to get here but it is an absolute cracker. The new AI and better handling make it feel like it is a totally new game (which is most likely is). Love it.

reviewText:
Pwah, PUT YER READING GLASSES ON! I'm delivering an indepth review.
Ok where do I start. I've followed Codies ever since Colin McRae Rally 2.0 (as stated in my previous reviews for Codies games) as an avid racer I couldn't wait to see what they could do with their first Next Gen release for Formula One.

Well for a start I can see a repeat of their first series into the F1 Franchise with F1 2010. No safety car, non-dynamic weather, average AI. But that slowly built up as the sequals were released so I am hoping next years game will be more feature full.

Focusing on this game. F1 2015 brings the 2015 season and the 2014 season into one package for the next gen consoles.

GRAPHICS: The engine has been rebuilt (so they say) and everything has been reworked. The game looks and feels great, running at 60fps at 1080p on both my laptop, and my PS4 and looks absolutely stunning. The game looks its best in the wet weather where the detail is immense!

HANDLING: The handling of the game has been reworked so the car feels more realistic but I feel the car is almost way to easy to stop under braking. It feels like ABS is always on, even though I don't use the Driving Aids. Wet weather conditions will make any racer nervous to stray off the racing line to attack, as you will most likely end up in the gravel.

DAMAGE: This is one big letdown. The damage model of the car is virtually unchanged, while it may be easier to clip your front wing, its taken a backwards step compared to other games like Project Cars, rFactor 2, Asseto Corsa. Even their own DIRT Rally has a better damage model and it was released before F1 2015. There seem to be NO MECHANICAL FAILURES, like brakes, ERS failure, flat spots and the only time i get a puncture is if I deliberatly punt the car into the wall hard enough.

AI: The AI have been reworked as well, I play on legendary settings and they seem to manage their tyres better while still keeping up with me, often performing better. I tried some tyre savings but dropped off the pace, may have to change my tactics. AI like to make mistakes, sometimes clashing with each other and losing a front wing but nothing special compared to f1 2013. Another thing is if an AI hit you (yes HIT YOU) they tend to push your car into the wall, or spin you, while they continue as if there was no contact.

REPLAYS/FLASHBACKS: Replays now allow you to see the action from not just your car, but any car you wish so you can see just how awesome that crash was. However the replays are slighty broken as once you perform a flashback you cant go back and rewind further. This made me lose a race as while overtaking a backmarker on the last lap I got hit and spun into a wall, as I used a flashback I hit the button too late and it flashbacked to after the spin and was unable to use the feature again to get out of it.

SETUPS: Setups are ok, a few nicks from me, I cannot change a setup during a quick race with no practice and no qualifying. Or if it rains while the qualifying was dry on low downforce packs the AI seem to have a leading edge in the rain, almost like their setup changed. Funny that.

In closing the game is the start of new things to come, it has bugs, its not feature full but its a good start of the Next Gen series. Compared to Dirt Rally (the sister game released prior) it feels like the F1 games don't get the development they need to be a great game for racers and feels unfinished. I still recommend this game however.

reviewText:
F1 2015 is a nice racing game for huge Formula One Fans just like me or for non Formula One Fans. Of course its not a hardcore racing simulation so dont expect it have nice physics like rFactor 2 for example. But for in between its a nice game, you can have much hours fun in the Singleplayer (Just like me). Also it runs on near Max Settings and high Frames per Second on those (my) PC components:

- Intel Core I7 3770K 3,4GHZ
- Nvidia GeForce GTX 750Ti 2GB VRAM
- 8GB RAM Kingston HyperX

So yeah, this proofs that a GTX 750Ti can run this game on near Max settings @ 60FPS. Because much guys complaining about F1 2015 how bad the Framerates are, how bad it was ported, bla bla.. I dont have Problems with the game, very rare little bugs but they aren't a Fun Killer.

The Online Part of F1 2015 is not so good like the Singleplayer, because of different reasons when you play with randoms. (For Example lags, hackers, unfair driving, ramming, etc..)
But you can enjoy the Online Part of F1 2015 too if you are just playing with your friend in a private session (1vs1 for example) and with a couple of AI Drivers loaded.

So, i definitely recommend to buy F1 2015 for PC.

reviewText:
After a bad start when F1 2015 was released, i genuinely thought i'd wasted my money getting the game. Now though, after all mthe updates that have been implemented to the game, my perspective has completely changed. More challenging, realistic, fun and competitive compared to the previous F1 releases. Codemasters had done a fantastic job with f1 2010 through to 2013, 2014 let them down a bit as the final game appeared to be just a car/sound update of 2013.
There are still areas of the game that need improving: parc ferme needs fixing so that tyres used in Q2 are locked for the race start unless its alternate weather, own use of ERS was promised by codies but so far hasn't appeared. Also, multiplayer still doesn't support a full compliment of 20 human racers, still the 16 from the previous titles.

Lets hope Codies can improve upon the current situation, but overall a good start for their first next gen F1 project.

Rating 7/10

reviewText:
I bought this racing sim/game recently and love it.  I'm only about 7-hours into it, but wow, great job with this release.  I just ignored all the negative reviews and jumped right in, knowing most of the negatives were prior to the many patches and fixes. My intorduction to 2015 was after all the new release hoopla and problems (just purchased 01/30/2016), and long after the patches and bug fixes were released, so I do not and have not suffered from all the issues you see in reviews that are 1-6 months old.   Also it's smooth as silk running at max settings with 1920x1080 resolution AMD 8320 8-core.

I have 2014 as well and have fully enjoyed that on the PS3 and also just bought it for my PC, adding some nice graphic mods - 2014 is great looking in it's own right but with the new visual mods it's fantastic and with very cool game play options.  With that said, 2015 looks a little better but not a huge leap from 2014 imo, especially with visual mods added to 2014 - but 2015 looks better non-the-less unmoddd thus far.  The one thing is I don't see MSAA antialiasing, which is weird that 2015 wouldn't have that setting.

Now the car and handling are much improved (ie harder to drive) with much better physics over 2014.  Need a very light touch on throttle and brakes or you'll feel like your driving on an ice rink (I only use medium TC assist, nothing else).  You have to finess the car handling and acceleration if you want to keep from crashing.  The first impression is the very real sensation and feel" of driving the real thing; a highly unstable and fast F-1 racer - much much moreso than 2014.

After driving 2015 for a several hours with practice laps/time trials
date: I jumped into 2014 and with all assists off it was almost easy and a little "rail like".  After all the difficulty I have with pushing the new 2015 platform it makes jumping into 2014 a much easier drive.  The actual feeling of driving in 2015 is there in all it's glory
hoursPlayed: and '14 is no slouch imo (I know the iRacing guys will probably laugh).  So I'll do most of my heavy practicing in 2015 and use 2014 to race online and for it's neat carreer mode and vintage racers.\n\nAnd the audio in 2015....wow

column19: I guess there are still issues with the netcode for 2015 so it seems as of right now most of the online F1 leagues are racing with 2014 until Codeies fix 2015 multiplayer - hopefully soon.\n\nAll in all I'm loving it so far.  Not that deep into it yet

reviewText:
I really love racing sim and I was really excited about this free weekend...
Unfortunately this game is sort of broken and that ruins what could be really awesome.

+ Great physics, feels really nice. Although I've never driven an F1 car I'd say it feels pretty realistic"
+ Graphics are pretty good
+ Easy to turn all assists off and jump into sim mode really quickly

- Draw distance on mirrors is abyssmal
- Volume is far to loud even on lowest
- Hard and higher difficulty A.I. will literally PLOW YOU OUT OF THE WAY ruining the game at these levels
- You get penalties for any collisions even if the A.I. are completely at fault for the accident (I.E. plowing you out of the way from behind)
- Performance is TERRIBLE. i5-3450 + GTX 960 4GB + 12GB of RAM on my system
date: and this game runs at 45fps most of the time on highest settings (1080p)
recommended: comparatively Dirt Rally looks better and runs at 80 at max settings/1080p.\n\nTwenty dollars is far too much for this
hoursPlayed: maybe ten if it really goes on sale would be worth it

reviewText:
This came out with tons of bug, so I waited and bought it on a sale after a few patches. Now I must say the game runs like a charm in my system, I've found zero bugs.

I run it on a i5 4440 with a 970GTX, 8GB of RAM, a SSD, Windows 10 and a 360 controller. Never had a crash, fps tank, controller issue or any other bug. Runs well and always at 60fps.

The game is great. Good graphics and amazing AI. Good balance between arcade and simulator. For me is the most engaging racing game that I've tried, I love it.

The damage system is pretty basic, and there is no safety car :( which it's my main concern with the game. There is no career mode, and while I miss that it's not the end of the world. They say the multiplayer is a mess, I don't know, never tried it. I'm always racing the AI.

If you buy this game try it right away, in case you find bugs or issues and need to ask for a refund. But if you're lucky and the game runs well, then you'll find it worthy of your money.

reviewText:
So far so good. My Renault Engine hasn't blown off yet...neither has my computer!

GTX 970
I5 4690
16GB Ram
Everything at max, 60 FPS.

+ Lots of graphic options
+ Sounds
+ 2014 or 2015 season, you choose.
+ Seems well optimized

- TXAA and SMAA makes the game blurry
- Controller support (360) seems a bit off right now
- Cutscenes run at 30 FPS.
- Steam In-game overlay doesn't always work
- No safety car

Honestly, it's really barebone. The new graphic engine looks good, but like I said, a bit blurry. The cars control much differently with a wheel than with a controller, slippier with the former.

There has been a patch released on July 10th to fix the crashes some users are reporting.

reviewText:
This game is actually more fun than previous F1 2014 and here my reasons :

Much better and more aggressive AI sometimes even too aggressive (made me crash 2 times after overtake they wouldnt leave too much space).
Ai now has more B*LLS to overtake.
I dont miss carreer mode since i hated that when i change time from Ferrari to Mercedes (Hamilton or Rosberg would disaper) i would like to see like transfer system so other drivers could change teams too.
I dont miss safety car there wasnt too much its activity on F1 2014 either execpt for Monaco i guess.
Car feels so much better than previous games i play on keyboard still so its kinda of improvment for me .When traction control is off on keyboard i couldnt handle the car it was spinning i guess i need to get more feel to it .

Now graphics :
I have I5 and GTX 750 and i have solid 60FPS on 1080p ultra settings which is enough for me BUT
environment looks extremly bad its all pixleted. Even other cars looks bad . I hope they will fix this somehow.

I am very big fun of F1 and F1 games and i really hope they will do something about PC version.
I wont give up !

reviewText:
F1 2015, save your money. AI drivers are too aggressive and too fast in the straights, yet you can pass them in the corners every time.  Forget Multiplay. The real 2015 F1 cars have Kers but there doesn't seem to be a Kers button, only a DRS. Huh?

The one thing I like is that the time trial. It allows you to have ghost cars using other players times, so you are constantly trying to best another players time, and when you do you get access to a faster player and his set ups. Good idea.

Graphics are better I guess but you'll need a new computer to see them. I have an I7 3770 with 1 gb Nvida card and 8gb ram but have to run in low res mode.  F1 2012 works fine.

All in all a dissappointment from F1 2012, the last game I bought in this franchise and overall a much better experience.

Do yourself a favour, play Race 07 and the tons of mods available, then play F1 2015 and then tell me you like this game better. The Race 07 graphics are not as good, but the physics are better, the AI is better and adjustable, the loading screens are faster, the multiplayer is better and it has everything except flashback that you constantly need with F1 2015 because of the bad AI. Kudos to Race 07 and it's 8 year old engine.  Codemasters need to take a page from Race 07 and deliver a better game experience.

reviewText:
Purchased after the most recent patch. There are still some minor graphical glitches such as the back right tire flickering in and out in certain view modes but overall this game is very good now. The graphics and handling are much improved and really are quite ridiculous when you turn them all the way up. You get a good feel for how your cars handling changes as the race progresses and all of the modes are pretty accessible, (I have not tried the very hard pro mode yet). I would recommend getting a steering wheel for this game as it is difficult to play with anything else. I do have a fairly new gaming setup so keep that in mind when considering my review.

Graphics- 8/10 would be 10/10 if there were not the minor annoying glitches
Game Modes- 7/10 fairly typical for a racing game but its tried and true
New Handling System- 10/10 i really enjoy this aspect and its a big improvement from 2013 which is the last F1 game I played

reviewText: Well I'm a huge F1 fan so my opinion on this game is gunna be biased but this is probably the best F1 game Codemasters have made. The AI actually fight you and go for overtakes and do crash into others and you WHICH is realistic but makes everyone rage. The graphics are beautiful and I like the 2014 content really but it seems less worked on. The online actually does work I've raced against other people and they are actually good. Cars are realistic, fun and hard to drive.\nBad stuff though: No safety car. Add this Codemasters in next update or explain why it's not in the game. No Career but I understand why Codemasters killed it to help with the license. Can be glitchy. It forgets my steerign wheel controls even though they're saved under custom. Legend AI are too easy won 17 races as Daniel Ricciardo. And the skins of cars are wrong at some tracks e.g. McLaren new dark and red livery wasn't on the car until Spain I think so I shouldn't be able to have it until Spain afterwards.\nOverall I'd say 8/10 haven't got any problems with it. Recommed to buy in a sale when there's more updates.

No idea why its reviewed so badly, the launch of the game had a pre-release tag on it, and included few major bugs and glitches, that's probably a part why its reviewed so badly if u buy a pre-release game you have to accept the fact that there might be some bugs and glitches still there. I pirated the game first to test it out, but after that i got the game myself and its really good, the driving models and physics are the best yet.

Yes i know the multiplayer is full of rammers etc... but that's in pretty much every multiplayer race game...
Just get into a online league.

I would recommend getting a steering wheel for this game as it is difficult to play with anything else. I do have a fairly new gaming setup so keep that in mind when considering my review.

Graphics- 8/10 would be 10/10 if there were not the minor annoying glitches
Game Modes- 7/10 fairly typical for a racing game but its tried and true
New Handling System- 10/10 i really enjoy this aspect and its a big improvement from 2013 which is the last F1 game I played

reviewText:
These are my updated F1 2015 impressions. Codemasters have tossed out every part of their old games and built a new one from scratch. It doesn’t look, feel or sound like the previous titles. It lacks features from the older titles, but the core game is much better than it ever was.

Like the other Codemasters F1 games, F1 2015 requires concentration and finesse. I’m playing with a gamepad, and you just can’t mash full throttle and steering and hope to get to the other side of a corner pointing the right direction. The game uses the full possible range of analogue control available to create a remarkably deep and rewarding driving game. It’s the only racing game where I’m happy to drive around the same circuit for 20+ laps, as every moment is unique depending on the tire type, their temperature, the weather, the car damage, and whether I’m starting to feel fatigue. It strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and hardcore simulation, which I feel most simulators don’t hit. Compared to the earlier titles there’s a whole new level of realism, where the aerodynamics and skidding feel just right. When you’re driving on a rainy track and you lose traction, the sensation of sliding on the track is immediately understandable. You can feel how you could have prevented it, and encourages you to do better in the next corner. The way the game communicates what the car is doing to you, even through the imperfect medium of a gamepad, is better than any other racing game I’ve played.

Visually it’s easily one of the best games I’ve ever seen, though this opinions appears controversial from what I’ve seen from other players. Like Alien Isolation the game uses several camera tricks that don’t show up in videos because of compression. Thanks to heavy post-process antialiasing and advanced motion blur there are almost no visible jaggies whatsoever. This makes the game look more like a CG movie than a videogame. There’s a remarkable sense of coherence to the visual style. The cars and the tracks appear to be part of a larger world, and objects far off in the distance have a sense of presence that is unusual in games. It feels huge and convincing. This coherence was clearly a goal of the developers, as they’ve made improvements in pit animations. The transition animations between menus, and when you drive out to the track are all much more polished than before. There’s just a couple jerky movements here and there for the sake of speeding up the pace. I prefer how this looks to Project Cars, and any other racing game out now for that matter. The only comparable game is Driveclub. It makes me feel like I’m there, like it’s a real place, like it’s a part of a bigger world like nothing else I’ve played.

Other details like the audio has been overhauled. Engine sounds aren’t as in-your face as before, as they now sound as if they travel through the air before hitting you. Same with other sounds like the audience, reflections against walls, and tire noises. They’re all filtered differently based on where the camera is placed, none sounding like simplistic game sounds of the past. A new addition is the wind noise which changes based on car aerodynamics. If you damage the front wing, the air audibly travels differently across the car, making quite alarming sounds if it’s heavily damaged. You can hear the role it plays in keeping you on the track, even if you might not understand it on an intellectual level. This is easily the most advanced racing game sound engine I’ve heard, packed with subtleties that help make the long races more interesting.

If you played any of the other F1 games, and have been waiting that next-gen upgrade before jumping in again, this is it. It doesn’t have as extensive career options as before, but the Championship mode will still take you ~20 hours to run a single season, so it’s mostly a loss for those who are in it for the long haul. I’m fine with how this game turned out. In fact it’s better than I dared hope. The depth of the core game mechanics, the coherence to the visual design, the rich audio design, makes this a no-brainer recommendation. I’ve had no technical issues, and most of the crash bugs other people have reported have already been fixed.

reviewText: I dont get all that negativity for this game,sure its still little bugfest but thats vhere bad thins end(and if you want stupid and unrealistic 7 year long career mode,just go and play games like Need for speed for kids,this is Formula one game and what you got is chapionship in one season(or two in this game sience you get F1 2014 as well) like always before in Formula one games).I am something like veteran Formula one game player on PC ,i start with legendary Grand prix 2(and then GP3 and GP4,and also EA Formula one series)and ofcourse i play all recent F1 games from Codies,and to be honest i dont like those games that much ,mainly physics in those games feels bad,too arcady cars act like they have no weight etc.So i find my self very curious about new physics engine in F1 2015.After two days with this game i am more than happy with F1 2015,the physics is finally what i want you just feel the weight of the car much more and driving even with gamepad is fun and at the same time very challenging as you try handle all those torgues from hybrid engine(it feels to me like GP3 with traction control OFF).Next thing is much better graphics than before,in some cases(try night race at Singapore with heavy rain)is just absoluttely jawdropping,but with that said the optimization of this engine is just great(if you have something like cheap mainstream GPU like r9 270 ,GTX760 or GTX960 you can play this game wit 1080p high sets with stable 60fps  without any drops even in thunder storm(am look at you project CARS(-;).Next is sounds which are also very good,and finally the much better Ai that feels much more agressive than before and act like real drivers.All and all i am very impressed with F1 2015 and i have strong statement for you....this game is by far best Formula 1 game on PC i played the atmosfere is sometimes just stunning!!!.If you are heart beat fan of Formula one and racing games dont wait and buy it,you wont be dissapoited.

reviewText:
This is a truly amazing F1 game but lacks a lot of game modes. The car physics feel fantastic and the force feedback is great. You can really feel the bumps and speed thanks to the improved soundtrack and new engine which makes it feel and look like a totally different game to F1 2014. Graphics have been greatly improved and I can run it at a smooth 60fps maxed out at 1440p with gtx 780 SLI (Not sure if SLI profile is out yet). The AI feel more challenging on higher difficulties and use the track to how I watch F1 on TV. The new weather conditions look amazing and really change the way you have to drive compared to last years game and most of the tracks look great as well. Stormy weather conditions look photorealistic especially on the Singapor track. I want to mention that there are no safety cars in the game and I have no idea why. Also the hit collision is so bad you can get away with pretty much anything (hopefully a mod will come out to fix that just like F1 2014)

Pros: Greatly Improved physics
Greatly improved graphics (adds immersion especially with the soundtrack ingame)
Realistic AI
performance is good (While I cannot play in 4K as I get around 40fps I am waiting for an SLI profile to fix that and there is a benchmark you can loop to see performance like F1 2014)
Can choose to race in 2014 cars and season and 2015 cars and season
Amazing weather conditions (graphically and gameplay wise)

cons: No career mode
Cannot foward time in practice or qualifiying quick enough
Can be demanding if you have a lower spec machine (Lots of graphics options to tweak though)
Graphics are great comparing to F1 2014 but not the best compared to the newest racing games like project cars
Minimal style TV intro with commentary which could have been much more as it lasts for like 10 seconds.
No safety cars
Bad hit collision and damage

If you love F1 games or have an interest in F1 I would recommend this game only if you have a good spec machine, dont mind some of the missing game modes and enjoy racing games.
voteText: 19 of 42 people (45%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText: I am a huge F1 and so pre-ordered this game as soon as I could. I've only played Championship Mode and have not attempted online, but so far I am really impressed. Sure there are some bugs and the game is definitely not perfect, but nonetheless, it is very good. The areas where I've had the biggest issues are with the frame rate slowing down at braking points (gets pretty blurry, but only very briefly) and with the AI being fairly aggressive and not seeming to mind trying to get their nose embedded in your rear wing if you so happen to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. The AI issue doesn't happen all that often and only if you're really in the way, so its not that bad. The final issue is with the flashbacks. I try not to use them, but for anyone just starting out they are a great help. However, in this game they are very hard to use, once you select the place you want to restart at you go so quickly back to the game that it is very hard to control, at high speeds your car and the wall can end up being the same thing if you arent being careful.The last F1 game I had was 2013 and the actual racing compared to that is amazing. The wheel-to-wheel action is great and really presents a challenge. Obviously playing with a wheel helps that, so i cant speak about controller (gamepad) play, but the driving is fantastic. Im using an i5 and gtx 960, and am able to run the game on high settings. Even on high the graphics are, in my opinion, amazing. The slight blur that people have been talking about does exist, but it is hardly noticeable. Even though there are definitely some work and patches needed, I would recommend this game for any fan of racing and F1.

reviewText: TL:DR - Wait for steam sale.\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nPresentation and handling wise, this games a step forward although I still long for the days of Be a Driver" from 2010 when we had paddock access. It needed expanding
date:
not removing completely but I digress.
The new podiums feel stiff and awkward partly due to the poor character models.

You get two seasons worth of content in this package
recommended:
2014 + 2015 but a real missed opportunity by Codemasters to tie the two seasons together into some cohesive career mode. Instead you simply pick which seasons cars you chose to drive which other than aesthetics drive exactly the same.

Season mode has a fixed set of options regarding length and season types that can't be tweaked so if your doing a 25% race distance your forced to do 1 15min practice season and a 1 shot qualifying lap. No option to do a traditional qualifing setup. I can't understand why you would remove played choice from menu's that has been there since 2010.

Visuals are about the norm for the series with a really horrific motion blur and Depth of field effect added to hide the cracks
hoursPlayed: the much heralded 'new game engine' is clearly just an evolution of the EGO engine. If it isn't
voteText:
then they've gone very much out of their way to make it exactly the same in many ways. Another missed chance to really upgrade.

Everything else feature wise has had a massive step backwards. A very empty product. They've already confirmed there will be no DLC either so what you see is what you get. Very disappointing.

The core game underneath has potential.... I recommend a purchase but only once it hits the steam sales.

"

reviewText:
F1 2015 is the next official game of the F1 season brought to you by Codemasters. Last year they announced that, while still releasing F1 2014 in September as usual, they were just going to port over F1 2013 minus classic cars/tracks and alter the looks of the cars (and that they did). They did this because they were focusing on a brand new current gen F1 game that they were intending to release earlier in the year than usual. That game is F1 2015.

I've now played 2 hours of it and, combined with my experiences playing the official Codemasters F1 games since 2011, I feel I have a fairly decent insight of the game, so I'm going to go with the typical pros cons approach with some elaboration.

So, without further ado. Lets get started!


Pros:

+ While F1 2014 just felt like F1 2013 without the need to press the KERS button each lap, this game really overstates the changes that were made to F1 in 2014. Less rear grip, more torque, less fuel, harder tyres, and a reduced front wing width. Combined you can really tell the difference and it feels fantastic!

+ The game is beautiful. You get to see the tracks in full glory at the start of a race session, but the rest of the game (bar the driver models maybe) looks absolutely fantastic. With a pleasing to look at UI too.

+ The game sounds beautiful too. The low pitch roar (lets be honest, it's more like a purr ;) ) of those V6 engines, the whistle of that turbo as it spools up, the sound of the wind rushing past your cockpit, and the squeal of the tyres as your slide them over the curbs. All fantastic.

+ Customisation: While F1 games have always been fairly good in terms of customisation this one takes it to the next level. You can request alterations to wing tilt from the pit box during a race! That added, with the new radio chat (though you can not literally speak to your engineer on PC) you can even announce things like oversteer, loss of traction, and your engineer will suggest a course of action. I feel like Jenson Button already!

+ In my 2 hours of gameplay I've seen the AI drivers make plenty of mistakes. Which, can be annoying, but it makes it all the more interesting. Max Verstappen lost his rear going round a corner when he caught his wheel on the curb, spinning into me. Maldonado locked up on the entrance to a corner and bumped me in the rear. It's always nice to see AI drivers not being super duper computer driver guys.

+ This may seem like a minor point but trust me, it's so good that I feel it needs it's own point. You can finally spectate other drivers whilst in the pits in a quali or practice session! Complete with speed trap speeds and sector speeds. Want to see how your rival takes the track? Now you can!

+ The addition of the pre-race on grid line up, an aerial view of every track introducing a race, podium celebrations, and the UI and features inside the pits, you can definitely see that CM went for a more immersive feel with this game and I must say I really like it. Though, podiums make me a bit sad because no career mode.

+ CM have given us the 2015 season AND the 2014 season to play with making up for that dreadful F1 2014 game. So we get to enjoy 2014 as it was meant to be enjoyed.

+ It's worth noting that I have yet to try multiplayer but I did have a quick look in that section of the menu and it certainly seems there are far more options for matchmaking. Allowing choose skill level of your rivals, as well as picking and choosing various settings and assists to keep the races fair game.

+ Again, CM seem to have got the simulation/arcade balance right. The car and customisation feel good enough to satisfy a hardcore racing simer's needs but the game is completely friendly to a more arcade based user experience. This is something CM have done for the past 4 years and they have continued it on with this game.


Cons:

- No career mode :(. Personally, one of my biggest enjoyments of F1 games is making my own driver, stepping into a lower team's cockpit and working my way up to become a world champion. Sadly, in this game CM decided to remove that possibility. You can still do a career of sorts as an existing driver but it will only be one season (technically 2 I suppose if you do a 2014 season as say, Vettel, and then play a 2015 season as him too...) I have yet to start one of these though so I can't comment on R&D progression or that sort of thing. Oh well, looks like I won't be winning no races this year as myself.

- Now I can't comment for everyone but so far I've found the game much more favorable to play with a controller (an Xbox One controller to be exact which, due to windows drivers, is effectively an Xbox 360 controller). I think this is mostly down to my wheel's dreadful pedals though. I figured it was worth mentioning because Retrofly seemed to mention it didn't feel right to him with his wheel. But this one is subject to your own experiences.

- Still can't pit manually. Boy I'd love to do that. To make matters worse, when you floor it into the pits (tested at Silverstone) once you cross the pit speed limit line the car instantly decelerates to the pit limiter speed which is very strange to experience. A minor gripe though.

- I can't find an option to turn off or reduce HUD. I generally like to play my F1 games HUD free and the addition of the radio chat enforces my preference, but so far the only way I've noticed how to reduce the HUD is to go into cockpit view, and even then it leaves like current position and lap time at the top. Retrofly said there was an option but I haven't found it.


In summary, this feels like a massive improvement from the previous F1 game, much in the same way F1 2013 felt to F1 2012. And while I'm disappointed in the lack of a career mode it certainly doesn't lack in content giving you the 2014 season for free. Like I said, to me the game feels more friendly using a controller which has really been the same in all F1 games to date from Codemasters, so if you're looking for a race sim to play with your fancy racing wheel I might recommend something like Assetto Corsa. But if you're an F1 fan looking for a quality F1 racing game to play, or even just looking for a decent racing game that isn't a hardcore simulator as such, this game is probably more suited to you.

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
First off it's gorgeous. I mean absolutely stunning. I actually feel like I'm strapped into one of these beasts of auto innovation. You feel the raw power of the engine and the tyre wear is a lot more noticeable. Even on a 360 controller. If you're a formula fan and enjoy the previous installments of the franchise, then 2015 is a must. I've put in a full practice session at Melbourne and the track looks absolutely stunning. The engines sound pretty accurate as well.

The only down side is I'll bet getting it for Xbox One also and probably play more on it since I can use kinect to chat with the race engineer. Not sure why it couldn't be done on PC but I'll leave that to the technical experts at Codemasters to explain(although it's not really needed). One last thing is the speed trap information I noticed they added but I couldn't find my speed, however watching the onboard video of the AI drivers I got a pretty good idea I was fastest through it.

All in All so far 10/10 glad I bought it and saved $5USD.

reviewText:
To be fair to this game, it doesn't exactly warrant as much negativity as it's getting. The game was very unstable prior to the hotfix (10/07/15) but is since far more stable and I personally haven't experienced any crashes. The optimisation is class; everything maxed out at 1440p and I never drop below 60fps whilst driving (4790k, GTX 970), though I have heard that Crossfire and SLi don't work.

It is a fun game, but the simulation element when it comes to car handling and feel is absolutely minimal, even more 'arcade' feeling than the previous games. I've tried multiple settings with my wheel (Thrustmaster Ferrari F430) and with my Xbox 360 gamepad but I just don't get the feeling that the tyres and track are connected, it actually takes a lot of effort to put the car into a spin, on purpose without dropping down into first and purposefully doing a donut, the car generally feels like it's floating around the track; I play with all assists off.

The AI are hit and miss, it seems to vary between practise and qualifying and the actual race; in the actual race, the AI will follow blue flag rules if you're passing some backmarkers, whereas they won't in practise and qualifying. The aggression of the AI has been turned up a notch and it's both good and bad, good because they provide a bit more of a challenge, bad because they'll often just charge straight into you like you're invisible.

Some options are missing, such as career and co-op career. The classic career mode I would have liked to see, moving your way up (or sideways) through different teams as you progress through a career for me, added to the all important immersion. It has instead been replaced with 'Championship season' where you take over a real driver and can't change teams, and 'Pro season' where you're locked into a full race weekend with no assists, parch ferme rules, legend AI, full damage etc...

The engine sounds are absolutely spot on, the engines sound authentic, but the engineer random babble (he never shuts up!) and the menu music can get annoying.

The graphics in my opinion are a backwards step overall, the game looks decent, but not as good as previous iterations in this franchise in certain areas, for instance, I haven't experienced any blocky graphics or texture pop-in, but the cars themselves don't look as good, the mirrors have this strange slideshow thing going on, the AO isn't that strong even when set to X16 and it all has this strange blur effect.

As for multiplayer, I can't comment on it as I'm not interested in it for this particular game.

So do I reccommend it? Yes and no; it is a fun game, but it is not worth the Steam retail price of £39.99. It would be a fun little pastime to snap up on sale though.

reviewText:
Hi all,

Im not a hardcore fan of F1,

However i do own all the other F1 titles in the codemasters series & have enjoyed them with a racing wheel.

This is my first review I've written ever. So please be kind.  haha

This new version has the  latest season for 2015, new graphics. great camera angles & terrific replays. Obviously never driven an F1` car myself, but the handling feels quite good - you cant just tap the brake & expect to make it through a corner. cars do understeer alot through braking. AI seems really competitive too.   Graphics look less vibrant & cartoony than the previous versions, it has somre sort of filter on it so it looks like you are watching vision from the TV telecast - if that makes sense?

It is missing career mode, split screen racing.  However it does come with 2014 season as well.  Codemasters will be releasing performance data updates soon to align it with the real season shortly too.

Very enjoyable game so far for over an hour I've played it for.

I think some people maybe put off by the steep min or max PC specs.  I can re-assure everyone this game plays & looks spectacular even on min specs it will run lightning fast even on 1080P.  I had everything running on high to ultra high as a test - & frame rate was still solidly running on min 50fps+

My specs are entry level Alienware Alpha PC console..
-- not too hardcare of a  PC.

Base model..
Intel i3 2.9ghz (dual core)
8 gigs ram (upgraded from 4gb)
Standard 5400rpm hdd & GPU provided.

Hope this helps in some way.

thanks for reading.  Phil

reviewText:
Ok so... the game has bugs, the xbox 360 controller bug is particuarly annoying! But.. when on track, this is most fun i have had with a codemasters F1 game. The car feels lively, especially under braking, in the wet it is a total handful! I actually need to use my wing mirrors against the AI in this game, they seem much more concious and willing to attack.

Best of all.. in previous games i have felt like i was the only influencing factor in the race, if i didn't cause something to happen, it would be proceedural and finish to the expected result. Rather than action only happening directly around me, the race actually feels alive, overtakes, incidents and mistakes seem to happen around the track.

Some of the previous features are missing, such as career mode.. the line from Codemasters is that people rarely finished career mode and wasn't worth the time, the response from the internet seems to disagree.. but ultimately this is something that they could change post release if they wanted to. And hopefully will.

The audio in the game is brilliant, the engines sound much better than previous games, (particuarly the Honda)! And your race engineer is much more useful! The little race intros from David Croft (and Ant Davidson i think?) do bring more of an event feel to the race and good for the first time around, but i have already started skipping them.

The core of the game for me is how the racing feels, and in that category this game is brilliant, their best yet. The missing game modes are garnish, the bugs will be fixed, the racing is what matters. Although this game feels as though it was rushed over the line, it is fun and challenging in a way that none of the previous games have been.

I understand the frustrations of others but i can't enjoy this game as much as i have and give it a negative review. Thumbs up.. now fix the bugs Codemasters!

reviewText:
I feel like I should start off by explaining what exactly were my expectations for this title.

First of all, it is a multiplatform title with a relatively short development cycle, so I certainly didn't expect mindblowing visuals. I also did not expect anything resembling sim-like physics. You can get that in iRacing, don't expect any of that here (or in Project CARS for that matter).
I expected more emphasis on physics, however, and on car setups, though not too much.
Also, I personally do not care for the career mode or anything of that sort. In all of my previous F1 games I played as Mr. Player One with a plain white helmet.
I also expected a reworked AI. I played Project CARS and AC both, and in both cases I was very disappointed with the AI. Especially in Project CARS' case the AI was far too agressive.

With that in mind, F1 2015 ticks almost all the boxes in my books. The visuals are solid, though not all that impressive, certainly not as good as Project CARS, but that was to be expected.
In terms of actual driving, I was pleasantly surprised with the new physics model. It makes driving challenging, but it leaves you room for mistake, even with no assists on. The flexibility in terms of setups was also better than I expected. You can now change differential settings and there is no arbitrary ride height" setting
date: now you change it by altering the suspension settings. For some reason there is no garage setting for brake balance. I am not sure if setup changes actually affect the performance all that much
recommended: but so far so good.\nThe AI was by far the biggest improvement in my books. Now it actually tries to defend! AI drivers will at least try to keep their line into the corner

reviewText:
- AI

AI are improved, they will try to keep their position and race side by side. They don't give up as easilly anymore. However they still go double file into the first corner on race starts which is completely bonkers and unrealistic. They are generally more competitive, however they still take some corners unrealistically slow or fast which is a real bummer.

- Controls

It's fine with a 360 controller, infact its very playable. Came 3rd as Raikonnen with no assists against expert AI in my first race. However, when first starting the game it couldn't recognize what i was using for acceleration. I had to go into control setup and rebind everything on my gamepad to make it work. Also there are no deadzone settings within the game (they do exist in XML files though) and the gamepad deadzone is way too small making going in a straight line quite scary.

-  Gameplay

It plays like the previous games, there really isn't a big difference. People who claim this to be anywhere near a sim have no idea what they are talking about. This is still extremely arcade and handholdy in nature, and thats ok for what it is. If you want a sim go play iracing, AC or RF2, this is a realistic" game. The only real improvement to the "physics" and i use that term very loosely
date: is that it's not as frustrating as the previous years because you have a tiny bit more control.\n\nNo career mode and i don't care. It has seasons (2014 and 2015) single race and time trial. I'm totally fine with that

reviewText:
I'm honestly quite glad I tried it out before I refunded. Dispite all of the negative feedback for crashing I have not yet come into contact with any game breaking glitches.

The game itself plays well, the optomization is superb (My current PC doesn't meet the  requirements and is still playable). The subtraction of thee career mode is a very large negative, as that and multiplayer were my most played gamemodes on previous installments.

The season mode plays well, I got through a full 100% race with no major issues (Other than my engineer who told me to go on another set of inters as my oppoments switched to prime).

Overall it is a solid game, maybe Codies can produce an update that give us the career mode everyone wants.

reviewText:
Win7-64, i7, Nvidia Titan, 32GB.

Had a few races now.
Brief summary:

Positives +
+ This game is just about what I expected. Though I knew 'Career Mode' had been removed, and was aware of graphical issues for some.
+ The on-track graphics are beautiful at 'Ultra' settings, I haven't noticed any framerate issues thankfully but others have as I'm sure you're aware.
+ The TV Replays after races are actually watchable. It's rare you're hooked in by that, the TV-like coverage, camera placements are spot on.

Negatives -
- Lack of 2015 career mode is a negative, no ways about it. It feels like a downgrade from previous years. Like the mode has been sacrificed to get the game out earlier this season.
- 2/2 times loaded and booted from online races at startup. May just be me.
- The odd random glitch graphically. ex. A wheel visually flickering for half a lap.
- Steam Trading Cards yet to drop.


For me. This game just about leans towards a thumbs up.

reviewText:
Car physics have been completely overhauled since f1 2014 and feel much more realistic. The AI have also been updated, making for a much more challenging experience at the harder difficulties, while keeping it appropriately scaled for those who are new to the game and playing on easier difficulties. The graphics have also been updated and while they aren't a huge part in racing games, it's hard to not notice them when they look this good.

Multiplayer has been changed somewhat with more 'preset' lobbies to search in and you can now compete in races or lap around a circuit in time trial while waiting to find/join a game, which is a great addition. However, the multiplayer is region locked as far as I can tell which is somewhat annoying.

Career mode has been removed and replaced with a championship season" mode. It's the same thing except you play as a real life driver rather than having your name on the screen. Some people seem to care about this
date: some even not buying because of this but to me it's not a big deal. Personally
recommended:
I'd rather race as Ricciardo or Hulkenberg than replace them and race against their team mate. Split Screen co-op has also been removed but isn't really something that was important to me.

Some people are reporting various bugs but personally I've only had minor issues with my G27 settings and having to reset them every time I launch the game. A minor thing really but I expect that will get patched relatively quickly.

As someone who has bought many previous itterations of the F1 game series
hoursPlayed: I feel that this year
voteText: the changes are significant enough to warrant a purchase if you're unsure about buying the game
helpfulPercent: because it really is a new game you're getting
votesHelpful: not just v1.2 of the previous year's game like it sometimes felt."

reviewText:
Awesome game! Yes, it has some major bugs in it, but in the essence this game is killer.

PRO's
- Championship Season, finally I can play as a real driver
- Broadcast style is a cool addition
- Time trial mode, rivals!
- Driving in the wet. On Singapore. At night.
- Handling is much improved on the wheel. No longer too much wheel spin when exiting corners
- AI is much better now! They actually try to overtake me, something never happened in 2014.
- Driving in the wet. Again. But now because of the handling and the AI. The AI is a lot slower now and is now on the pace I am in the wet. Great! Wet racing is fun again.
- The engineer really gives you feedback while you are driving. He gives you feedback you really can use, on driving behaviour and setup improvements.
- The new layout is really awesome. Clean layout.
- 60FPS on my I5-2500K, 780GTX, 12GB RAM setup.

CONS
- A lot of bugs. And you can't tell me this has been properly tested.
- Resolution keeps going down to 1920x1080, but i have 2560x1440. I have fixed this inside the settings XML file, but it should be working propely.
- No out-of-the-box working settings for the G27. You have to tweak it yourself in Logitech Profiler.
- Really bad desicion to not let people adjust the session length on Championship Mode. (Only Q1,2,3 if 100% race)

I will keep updating this, but for the true F1 fan it is a must have. Great addition to the F1 games family. Yes it has some bugs, but they will be patched in the near future.

reviewText:
Update 12/7

Some more things I noticed:
- AI pace in a drying track is inconsistent. At one point after pitting for options I was able to set fastest laps, whereas the AI, still on intermediates were still only3 tenths off my pace
- In some of the broadcast replays, the cars in distance sound like remote control toys, especially noticeable at abu dhabi
- FPS randomly drops below 30 for 1-2 secs
- AI is very temparmental. They become suicidal at times and divebomb at times taking you out completely
- Some minor graphical glitches at times
- Really struggling with tire wear with the pad, even if I try my best to drive smoothly and on 'lean' fuel for longer periods

-------------------------

Having played all installments of codemasters F1 series, this is easily the best in terms graphics and handling. Even though the game is missing a lot of game features like splitscreen, online co-op, a career mode and scenario mode, if you really like racing and F1 in general, this is highly recommended.

+ Great graphics, 1080p with stable 60+ fps on 970 gtx
+ AI is much improved!
+ Driving in the rain requires skill, but very satisfying to get right. Unlike F1 2014
+ Broadcast presentation and replays highly add to the 'raceday' immersion

- Weird blur effect in distance
- Missing game modes impact the longevity
- Really damped vibration on xbox 360 gamepad
- Damage model?!
- Occasional crash during quitting the game

reviewText:
To be honest I was really skeptical about this game and after the release I was even more due the negative reviews being it buggy or handling being bad, you name it. I'm sim racer from head to toes and sims like rFactor and iRacing are the thing.

I can't really even believe that I own every F1 CM from 2010 to 2015 now. Here's my opinions about previous titles:
2010 was ok, didn't even own a wheel back then.
2011 is most likely the best one for me, but it had lots of bugs, mainly save corruptions.
2012 is definately the worst ever, the handling was über clunky and it just had very frustrating feel for me.
2013 was close to 2011's feel. Solid sim-ish-cade racer.
2014 was obviously something different as engines changed to V6's (like it does matter in game vs irl, duh). Overall feel was quite good, but lot of the time it felt like the tire spinning was really artificial.
Well this game, I was told by another sim racer that it is surprisingly very good. So I took the risk and gave it a go. For me as in, does it even work? No problems at all, which surprises me a lot. FPS is around 70-80 with high settings, so no optimization issues atleast on my side. Handling is really good, shockingly good, and for the first time you don't need to fart around with the wheel settings to have it at 270 degrees, to be able to drive even close to like normal human being. I'm using 450 degrees, feels great, but I might change it to match the ingame wheel (somewhere around 540 degrees). The wheel i'm using is Logitech G27.

Racing against the A.I is really fun. Some people have said that the A.I just runs on them and crash them out. After few races I've had, if we collide, the case has usually been that I haven't given enough room to the guy next to me and then lost control of my back end, when my back and his nose have contacted. I've been driving on legendary difficulty, it could be even harder but it's ok. Don't know about the lower difficulties, but they go quite aggressively for the overtakes and if you left space too much in to the corner, they go for it if they close enough. I had few chills when I was driving behind Williams in Ferrari, I just couldn't catch in the straights enough to go for the overtake and this happened many laps, is this season 2015 or what?

So racing itself, bloody awesome. But there's problems too.

Firstly graphics. Their ok, nothing that explodes your consciousness, but there are few things I want to point out:
Motion blur - feels like the games wants you to look at your cars nose. Everything in the distance (where you should look at) are too blurry. It makes me feel like I'm going crosseyed. In the pause menu you can see everything coming more tidy.
Shaking - this and blur makes it even worse, I'm not saying it horrible, but those things shoudn't exist, atleast there should be an option to change these.
Steering wheel bugs - when you change your view, firstly it centers your wheel and secondly, doesn't respond for a little while. It's not big of a problem though if you're driving with same view all the time.
Graphical bugs - In chase cam, my left rear tire is flickering, and sometimes in cockpit view the wheel starts to do it's own screen tearing looking party. There are many others, but I'm lazy and I just want to end this damn review.So overall very very good, but if you planning to buy it, play safe. Wait through the possible patches.

reviewText:
Not perfect but 2015 makes important strides in areas that really matter. Finally we see independent temp and wear stats for individual tyres for example and at last it feels like your driving style an dpit strategy choices have a gebuine effect. (I will update this review when I have a better feel for tyre changeover dry to wet). The physics model seems much improved, as ever the game is very well optimised and I've not been encountering many of the bugs others have drawn attention to - agin though your mileage may vary. As with any racing game, if changes effect driver performance negatively, that inclines people towards slating the game so do bear that in mind when wading through reviews - the same applies to mine which is written after discovering that the reworked physics and handling suit me very well.

The reworked race engineer is an excellent addition, giving genuinely helpful insight and data when you need it. The dynamic weather and track evolution works great also - this is easily my favourite game in the series to date.

However, there are some cons. Firstly, the UI can be more than a little frustrating and driver AI seems to have gone backwards against last year, with drivers being often reckless an dunyielding even on out or in laps. The broadcast style commentary is a great touch but sadly it's badly delivered and doesn't seem authentic somehow.

Still no ability to design your own helmet or pick your own race number, which seems to me to be a set of features that would require minimal work to implement. Would love to see a custom driver profile and have elements of that reflected in Crofty's commentary.

The lack of career mode and safety car are bigger issues and a surprising sacrifice for codies to make, however it's not impossible for these to be implemented later. This doesn't excuse the oversight however. The inclusion of the 2014 season was a nice touch and I think we're all glad Manor made it into the game for release.

In summary, I would definitely recommend. However bear in mind it may take a few patches to resolve some of the issues others are encountering so it's hard to be totally effusive wit my recommendation. In any case, the series is moving in the right direction and this is to be appluaded. The game veers more towards sim and less arcade when compared to the previous titles and if that's your bag, you'll be well catered to.
voteText: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Personally, i'm very impressed with 2015. If you're a fan of F1, and want to drive F1 cars, then this is for you (if you have a decent FFB wheel). If youre looking for a game with lots of gimmicks, like reading emails and changing teams, then one of the predecessors will be better for you.

Yes, it has bugs, and yes it does feel kind of featureless compared to its predecessors, but right now, none of that matters to me. Hopefully bugs will be fixed, and no doubt the sequels with have more features.

But the reason i'm praising Codie's is the driving; No, its not Assetto Corsa, but its a hell of a lot closer to it than the absolute shambles of F12014!

Despite being perhaps slightly 'easy', ie. unrealistic amounts of grip, the driving is generally very intuitive, and natural for anyone who has played AC or any other Sim. Unlike 2014, where the physics just felt horrible, with oversteer feeling scripted, and far from natural, i find myself driving just as i do in AC, playing with the throttle for slight oversteerm, lifting off to the the fronts to bite, etc.

And the FFB is 100x better too, where i actually know with the cars doing! I can catch drifts now! Its not just complete guesswork as in 2014. I do feel it lacking in feedback for the first 20-30 degrees, and its lacks any sort of 'bite', but its miles better than before and completely playable and enjoyable.

What would i change? Well not much, maybe continue on the road to creating proper feeling and driving cars, which they've pretty much done, they just need to add a touch of realism, especiialy for the 'Pro' mode; Less grip, really feels like TC is on when its off, should be able to spin up the rears more, and lock the brakes too.

Another thing i would add is a virtual mirror at the top of the screen in Pro mode, since the wing mirrors are useless! And also some more info on the steering wheel screen, such as laps left, delta, gaps to players, tyre temps, especially since you cant get that info from the engineer on PC, and there's no HUD.

reviewText:
As someone who has played every F1 game since the original Psygnosis game on the PS1, I would say this game is a hit, despite the poor reviews. After reading some before I launched the game I was thinking, oh ♥♥♥♥, not another Arkham Knight!

Codemasters claim the game was built from the ground up, which usually spells disaster. I remember how Tony Hawk's Project 8 pretty much buried the series with its dreadful mechanics.

That being said, it's a much needed change for this series which has stagnated over the past couple of iterations. The handling is easier to understand and far less twitchy. Overall presentation appears better, too. Definitely a step in the right direction.

The performance is decent, getting 80-110FPS on my GTX 970 with all settings at max @ 1080p.

There are some cons though.

1 Blurry graphics at times, gives me the urge to wipe my glasses even though they're clean. This extends to granular detail on things that are seemingly not there or out of focus compared to the old versions.
2 AI seem to enjoy doing PIT maneuvers on you, causing YOU to get the penalty.
3 No safety car!
4 No career mode
5 Game crashes on exit

Those saying it's the worst game in the series clearly haven't played F1 '98 or any of Sony's PS2 'efforts'.

I hope for next year we can get an F1 Challenge 99-02 style game with multiple seasons that Codemasters have the rights to through a career mode. I doubt it, though.

reviewText:
This is By Far the best F1 game to date as the AI aggressiveness, car handling, braking, weight shifting/balance, and traction have been improved by a factor of 10, at least. The FFB for wheel controllers is much better than any previous F1 game as well, which is good cause for a racing sim you really need a wheel controller (if you don't have a wheel I mean why even bother with a racing sim game?). It probably will require some fine tuning in the settings for dead zone, linarity ect. more than the previous games did but once you get it right the difference is night and day.

Just make sure your wheel is supported on the site first. Also make sure you have the hardware, it Requires windows 64bit version and is a fully next gen game so if your rig doesn't meet or exceed the next gen consoles you might have performance issues. But if you do have a rig that's as good as a ps4 or xbone the performance, in my 100+ hour experiance, with an i7 and gtx780ti it's rock solid 60fps @ 1080 running ultra settings with vsync.

The major bugs have been squashed and only a few minor ones are left, nothing game breaking really. Though the multiplayer is really lacking and poorly done, the single player is solid. Really the only thing lacking in single player is the career mode is now a single 19 race season where you pick to drive as one of the real life drivers rather than create your own driver. Thus at the end of the season now you either have to pick the same driver and go again, or pick a different driver, rather than in the other games at the end of the season you'd get contract offers to switch teams. Really this is a minor thing and certainly shouldn't keep you from playing as every single other aspect has been improved so very much it makes the older games look like pale imitations.

Having played '13 & '14 here on steam the difference in simulation of the car is a generational shift. I can't properly express just how much better it is. The graphics are simply beautiful. Going back and playing '13 made my literally laugh at how poorly detailed it was. It looked like a ps2 game in compairision. It was also missing the proper scale that 2015 as well as the minor bumps and character that the tracks have which are present in the 2015 game. If it wasn't for the classic tracks and cars in '13 there would be zero reason for me to ever go back and play it.

All in all this game truly is the most immersive, graphically beautiful, and realistic F1 to date. Highly recommend to racing and F1 fans for singleplayer. If you want multiplayer, well don't look to any F1 game they are all dead in that area heh.

reviewText:
Do NOT buy if you are expecting a career mode.

Very good F1 game, one of the most authentic that I have played. Championship Season and Pro Season modes are fun, however I question the overall longevity of the game, as the game lacks any sort of career mode, where you create your own driver, working your way up from the lower teams to the top, as included in previous F1 games. I feel that all F1 games should have such a mode as this was the main part of the game that I had played in previous iterations, and the decision to leave out such a mode is one thatI cannot comprehend, playing as the real drivers just isnt the same. This left me at first, dissatisfied with my purchase of the game however, after a few laps in a few of the different cars I realised that I could still have fun with the game.. I just miss the career... and even the paddock style menu and other immersive features, that F1 2010 had... 5 years ago...

However, aside from that... the inclusion of the drivers and cars from both the 2014, and 2015 seasons is one I feel that the devs must be commended for. This added so much more to the game for me and I appreciate that they have taken the time to add last years teams, drivers and cars. My only major complaint with the game is no career mode. Heres hoping they add it back in F1 2016.

reviewText: This game is brilliant. I can't describe it in any other way than brilliant. Everything about this game is spot on. The graphics are fantastic, the handling is outstanding, the sounds are brilliant, the force feedback system is perfect (project cars level), the broadcast presentations at the beggining of each session is awesome and the engineer is helpful for once! This game is just amazing and really shows what codemasters can do. I would massively recommend this game to anyone. Ecspecially if you race with a wheel like me. Yes this game has quite a lot of glitches and the multiplayer is aweful. But, you have to give it time since it's been out they have been working on fixing these bugs and have already come out with two patches since it's release. So I don't see why people are complaining. I have read a lot of reviews saying that they have taken too much away from the game. All I can say to that is that you clearly don't play the game. They have added so much into this game. Yes they have taken away classic cars and scinario mode and even career mode but most of them were pointless anyway. Classic car mode was pointless as the cars handled virtually exactly the same as the 2013 cars just with different textures and sounds. Scinario mode was rubbish and boring and career mode is basically still there you just can't drive as yourself. Anyway they have added a lot more than they have taken away. For a start this is just a base game for future F1 games to come so give it time. Secondly they have added things like: Talking to your engineer, Pro season mode, podiums at the end of races, tyre blankets, grid overview at the start of races, broadcast presentaion by David Croft and Antony Davidson, 2014 season included when you buy the game not DLC, new enhanced AI that provide a fantastic challenge throughout a weekend (watch videos if you don't believe me), tweaking front wing in pit stops, new fun animation (when pulled into the pits etc.) and a brand new replay system with real world camera angles. Basically there is a lot in this game certainly a lot more than in previous games. Remember this game is like F1 2010 in the sense that it is a base model for future games to come. This game has been built completely from scratch and has the potential of being the best racing sim out there. In my opinion this game beats Project Cars and Assetto Corsa, not only because you're racing new up-to-date F1 cars but in many other ways such as: much better AI, handling model, graphics and force feedback. So if you're thinking 'should I buy this game?' my answer would be 1000000% yes! because it is fantastic. Just give it time and all the bugs will be gone.

reviewText:
Before you look at the red thumbs down and decide that this review is exactly the same as the other 500 negative reviews saying REFUND, let me explain myself.

I bought this game on pre-order because I am an F1 freak. Now that I played it, I would say that it is worth the 60 dollars if you manage to get it to WORK. On my cut price PC with only a gtx 670, 8gb of ram and a middle range quad core i7 (3990 or something like that) I have had NO FLAWS... yes I am telling the truth, NO FLAWS. I have enjoyed every minute of my 6 hours in game. The reason why I am giving it the thumbs down is not because of the blurriness or because of the lack of features, but because for most people it is unplayable. I am the only one in a f1 gaming group of 30 people who has been able to play this game for more than 5 minutes at a time. ALL of my friends have had CONSTANT crashes, fps drops, controller issues etc. *just note that their PC's are gaming built high spec machines*. The majority of people that have purchased this game are having issues with it. Don't get me wrong its a great game, but for 60 dollars its more of a gamble. If you want to take that risk, get the funds, click that purchase button. If it works, you will have a lot of fun. Otherwise, trust the steam refund


I reccomend that you wait until Codies gets their act together and patches this game

EDIT: New Patch on July 31st removes some major issues with the game. You can now customize your career mode" and your engine will no longer sponateously combust while exitting pit lane. I don't know about the FPS drops

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
(EDIT: Originally recommended this game, but read the last edit (at the end of the review) for my current opinion about F1 2015)

It's not a perfect game, but it's not as bad as most people make it sound like.

Yes, there is no career mode, but why do you need your own name in the game when driving a full season? I understand that you might not want to play as one of the real drivers but instead as yourself, but that experience was lacking. You didn't have a name that your engineer could say when talking to you, only nicknames or some common english names.

Multiplayer has always been bad across all the F1 games made by Codemasters, so what did you expect on day 1 after game release? On F1 2013 I couldn't find lobbies at all, in F1 2014 I didn't bother to try the online. I've seen F1 2015 live streams, and the multiplayer needs some patching, but I have tried it once, and you know what? It worked fine for me. I could race close to other people, no problem. One of the problems are people with  bad internet connections, so don't blame it all on Codemasters.

I have enjoyed Career mode so far, and yes I would like to call it career mode. The only difference is that you drive as one of the real drivers for one season, so get over it. I would recommend this game, but you do need a somewhat good PC. Average FPS: 30 (actually less after a patch that was released same day as writing this) with a Nvidia GTX 550 Ti on low settings. I know its a old PC, but optimizing the game would be a huge improvement.

Should you buy it?
If you're a cry baby or just like to blame game designers: just no, stay away, please.
If not, I think so. Career mode is really fun, with a much better AI compared to F1 2013 and F1 2014. They actually fight you and will try to pass you on corners, unlike older F1 games where they would back off.

EDIT 03/11/2015: As I mentioned earlier in this review: a patch was released and my average FPS was worse after that. The gaming PC I use 95% of the time is kinda outdated (NVIDIA GTX 550 Ti GPU). I Have not played the game in a long time, but I have not heard about any updates that really improves the game. So if you're playing the game on an older gaming PC, I would not recommend this game at all, as I got an average FPS of just below 30 at the lowest possible settings.

But as long as you got a decent PC then this is so much better than the previous F1 games by Codemasters. As I also mentioned: the AI fights back, where as in F1 2013 for example, they just didn't bother fighting you if you pass them.

EDIT 28/11/2015: This game is much better than older F1 games when it comes to AI, and I really like this game, IF it would run better. Terrible optimized as mentioned before. When they recommend a GTX 970 something is wrong. GTX 970 is a quite high end GPU, and a racing game does for example not have a huge open world to load, and physics arent as good/advanced as lets say rFactor 2, so in theory no need for a GTX 970 GPU if they just spent a little bit more work on optimizing the game. If they had just done that, then I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
It's a beautiful game, with lots of new features.

The graphics are amazing, the driving has been improved and the AI is spectacular compared to the previous titles. The overall rating for me is 7/10. It's really a good game.

It has many glitches (all of them fixed now), looks nice and it is different from the previous games that we literally burned playing thousands of hours. It is good that CM makes an effort to present a new game, not just an improved version of the previous one.

But I think that it is better to keep playing or invest the money on the previous titles. F1 14 is better and F1 13 is a 10/10. This game has less features than any other CM F1 game. It does not even have the old coop season.

For me this game is a 6/10.

reviewText:
Ok so it is much better. I was disappointed before, but after the latest update i have decided to try it out and i am much happier. The car is tricky to drive which i like, but from racing for last place, im suddenly in contention for being the fastest out there. The AI are much better. I am still struggling with finding the correct setup for my wheel, but that is minor compared to what it was like before. The throttle responds much better too, allowing me to balance out of the corners. I have been avoiding the game the past few weeks, but now I can sit down and work on improving my balance as it is finally working properly. It just needs focus, which I love. I hope they keep improving.

The camera work in the replays are excellent. No longer fixed camera points at areas around the circuit, it switches to different angles throughout. One lap it will show trackside, next lap it will switch to a helicopter view at the same corner, just like watching live races. I love it

I also love that for the first time since 2011, all 3 practice sessions are available as an option. Really allowing you to dial the car in.

4. Game crashing on exit is 100% of times

6. Tires recommendation needs to be worked. It was raining outside and option tires were being shown as faster

I hope codemasters can read this and address in future patches

EDIT2:

I enjoy the game each time more, despite of the issus above.
Codemasters, stay strong and focus on the fixes.
My PC is I7 4970K + 32gb ram + gtx 980 and runs at 100+ with geforce recommended settings, mostly ultra. Framedrop are there quite a lot but not unplayable at all.
Once the issues are address it will be among the best racing games.

EDIT3: Decided to change my review to negative after what codemasters did with the controls in 31/7 patch. This is not acceptable.

EDIT4: Time to change the review back to positive as the game has been performed better and no major issues found after the deadline issue reported above. I do not play the game online so my review is based on the single player offline experience

reviewText:
I have only played the game for a couple of hours, but feel I have played enough to give some kind of valid opinion. Note this is only based on the single player game as I don't generally play multiplayer.

The last F1 game I played was F1 2013, which was ok, but had a lot of flaws, in particular that the cars were unrealistically hard to drive. Since then I have got more into racing sims, Project Cars in particular, but Project Cars only has a few of the F1 tracks and as I like to watch F1, I wanted an updated F1 game that had all the tracks. I am not a hardcore sim player, but I find driving the tracks before I watch an F1 race weekend helps with the appreciation of the sport.

The graphics in F1 2015 are a nice upgrade over 2013, but I have a high end PC and it looks like Project Cars on mid-high settings. I went into the settings expecting to be able to improve a few things, but everything is maxxed out, so it feels slightly dated. They are perfectly acceptable to play though. The only thing that doesn't seem smooth is the animations of the other cars on track, which seem a bit jerky.

The physics and car handling are much improved over 2013, I drive with traction control on and have no major issues keeping the car on the track as opposed to 2013 that wanted to spin at every opportunity.

The AI of the other cars is better than 2013 and they do a reasonable job. It is just let down by some of the behind the scenes decisions the game makes, like if an AI car rear ends you, you are the one that gets a penalty. When I was on the last lap of a race (near the back - am still learning!), Rosberg won the race about a lap ahead of me and was soon on my tail racing me like it was for position while I was trying to catch a back marker.

Controls, I use a G27 wheel and it was detected and worked ok once I unplugged my X55 joystick which it doesn't like. Force feedback is a bit minimalistic, and a big downgrade from 2013 which was the best FF implementation I have found in a game. It doesn't give much feedback from the track, and collisions with other cars gives more of a constant rumble while you are in contact, it feels like a console FFB scheme ported over to a wheel, which feels cheap.

While the presentation of the game is quite slick and has more of a TV style than 2013, some of the UI options are baffling, including the use of F8 to do something standard, but by my wheel setup I only have a mini keyboard where F8 isn't simple to press. If you are doing qualifying, you can't come in to pits and say I'm done, you only have option to accelerate time which is only about 8x.

A baffling omission is lack of KERS, although it does have DRS.

Overall this is a long way from a perfect F1 game (as usual for Codemasters), but it is the best one out there and there is a lot to enjoy for an F1/racing fan. For general racing, I still much prefer Project Cars, but when I want my F1 fix, this satisfies my needs.

reviewText:
It's a beautiful game, with lots of new features.

The graphics are amazing, the driving has been improved and the AI is spectacular compared to the previous titles. The overall rating for me is 7/10. It's really a good game.

It has many glitches (all of them fixed now), looks nice and it is different from the previous games that we literally burned playing thousands of hours. It is good that CM makes an effort to present a new game, not just an improved version of the previous one.

But I think that it is better to keep playing or invest the money on the previous titles. F1 14 is better and F1 13 is a 10/10. This game has less features than any other CM F1 game. It does not even have the old coop season.

For me this game is a 6/10.
